Anecdotally, I can disprove the idea that it's just when you remember it afterwards. I was in one car crash in my life.

1. I don't drive. And I had rarely been in cars for a few years as I was living in London. But in the early '90s, a group of us went to visit friends in the countryside. I only say this to suggest that I couldn't have picked up anything from the feeling of the car to have known something was wrong.

2. I was in the back corner seat and had turned towards the person in the middle as we were talking. This means that I wasn't looking out of the front window. I was just looking at this girl's face and there was a 3rd person in the backseat behind the girl so I wasn't looking out of the back door window either.

I was talking and then time suddenly slowed. I remember thinking "Why on earth has time suddenly gone really slow."

A bit after I thought that, as I was trying to work out why time had slowed, I felt the car begin to lose control {going round a bend} and then swerve and we went into the ditch.

All this was still in slo-mo.

And it now sort of made sense that it was.

It wasn't really dangerous. The car wasn't going above the speed limit and the ditch was only perhaps 3 foot deep. None of the 5 of us were harmed. Not even any cuts or bruises.

But I 100% know I thought 'Hang on, why has time suddenly really slowed down' from before there was any indication there was anything wrong {when I was in mid conversation} until we nose dived into the ditch and stopped moving.

Once we'd made sure everyone was fine, I told everyone about the time going slow straight away and had been known to happen sometimes.

So it clearly wasn't me remembering it as that afterwards.

{And ftr, I was several years later in a minor plane crash. A plane was taking off from Bogota airport, accelerated and when it put the flaps down for take-off, the flap on my side fell off the wing. I smashed into the seat in front - we all did - and that was scary as it screeched to on the brakes. But that wasn't slomo. It was just normal. First I knew about it was when I slammed into the seat in front of me. Then I did have a bit of pain and was just worried about getting back home safely.}

So if it was memory, why wouldn't I have remembered that as slomo? That experience, of time going suddenly going really slowly and not having a clue why and trying to work it out is not something one could have imagined without experiencing it. Trust me.

About a decade ago there was a series on BBC with the Oxford Maths professor Marcus du Sautnoy. One experiment made him say his mind was completely blown and he didn't know what was going on with reality any more.

At one of the top London colleges, he was made to lie down on his back with two electrodes - one in each side of the lower back of his head. He was given two thumb button pressers, one for each hand.

He had to relax and look at the screen, and at random intervals, the word 'Choose' would appear on the screen, and when it did, and not before, he was to choose to press the left or the right button.

1. The electrodes in the back of his brain got which one he would pick right every single time.
2. But 7 seconds before the word appeared on the screen.
3. Which also meant that, given the timing between the word appearing was random, his subconscious also knew 7 seconds before the word appeared that it was going to appear in 7 seconds time.
4. So while he's lying there, not knowing when the word will appear, nor which way he'll choose, his subconscious knew 7 seconds before hand.
5. Every single time.

Now remember, this wasn't some youtube spoof.

This is a BBC science documentary presented by an Oxford professor, a Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS), the current holder of the Simonyi Professorship for the Public Understanding of Science who has been a fellow of 3 different Oxford colleges..

And he said after he had finished the experiment that he no longer knew what was going on with reality. That it made him doubt time and free will.

His brain had predicted when a random future event would occur.
And had predicted what he thought was his own free will choice.
7 seconds before hand.
Every time.

So if that can happen, is it not possible that in the car crash, my brain also knew the future and slowed down time in preparation?

As I say, all I know is that:
I noticed time had slowed down and was wondering why.
That this started before there was any reason for me to suspect anything was wrong - hence my surprise.
That while it seemed at the time like a good half minute or more, it was probably only a matter of seconds in real life given we could see the tyre marks and it had started before that.

Anyone got any thoughts on this?


Actually, there was one other time where things slower only with hindsight. In 2001, I was watching an Arsenal CL game in the upper tier of the North Bank at the old Highbury stadium. 2-1 up against Juventus with 4 minutes of normal time to go. Bergkamp got the ball on the edge of their box, and with 2 defenders around him, he drags the ball this way and that for about 5 touches. Another defender arrives and he keeps dragging the ball around under his boot, twisting and turning, before flicking it through for a run of Freddie Llunjberg who finishes first time.

I hadn't seen Freddie's run as I'd just been staring at the ball. Time didn't seem to be slow, it all felt normal, but I thought Bergkamp had had the ball at his feet for a good 20-30 secs. It was only when I watched the goal again on Youtube almost a decade later that I saw, much to my surprise, that Bergy had the ball for maybe 6-7 secs. I was thoroughly shocked.

Now that could just be memory, or perhaps a subconscious memory of watching a slomo replay on the big screen. But as I say, it didn't seem slow at the time. It just seemed speeded up compared to my memory when I watched it many years later on youtube.

But the car crash, with me thinking 'why has everything gone slow?' before anything went wrong shows to me that it really did slow down.

And the time it would have taken in real life, as opposed to the slo-mo I was in, would fit that evidence of the BBC doc where our subconscious seems to know the future 7 seconds before it happens.

All perception is memory. I'll swear I saw a SciShow video on the whole problem of how our brains make a decision a fraction of a second before we think we've made the decision, though that particular phenomenon (when better explained) should hardly be surprising to anyone who relies on reaction speed for sports or similar. We live a fraction of a second behind real time regardless of being in life-threatening danger or not. It would follow that when we turn off our perceptual filters (or adjust them to be hyper-focused on a single thing like a baseball), we've got a host more data to sort through and cram into the newly written section of our memory.

That said, I've been hit by a car on my bicycle and have taken several trips over my handlebars and pretty much all of my memory of those incidents was a blur almost immediately. I doubt I'm unique, so I'm thinking there is a subset of people who stop writing to memory while reacting to dangerously hostile circumstances. That or the brain injuries incurred made my memory skip. Either is plausible.

I personally think it's the density of the memory. In most situations, your brain only cherry picks specific bits of info and remembers it. When your life is in danger, it records every single detail, making a short memory feel incredibly wrong compared to others, purely because of the density of the memory itself.

Ok I have two hypothesis: Time dilation could be the result of improved attention and processing of specific kinds of information, which might include spatial, proprioceptive, and sound cues, as those were most likely useful for survival of our ancestors. Interpretation of written language is a very new ability and requires very specific processing in the brain, which comes with a cost in the time it takes. It makes sense that they can't read faster.
Another hypothesis for the falling experiment's results could be that reading the chronometer was not directly related to the danger they found themselves in, so that information was filtered out to focus on more relevant information.

While total processing power of the brain doesn't adjust when in dangerous situations, more of the available processing power is transferred to active observation, rather than thinking about what the person will have for lunch, or the report that they're working on at their job, etc.

It's not a matter of being able to suddenly process a bunch of things all at once, either. Each thing goes through the mind and is analyzed to determine if there is an individual danger from whatever is observed. Each frame of our perception is examined separately with all of our brain's attention. If the actions in that moment are observed to be less dangerous than an upcoming predicted event (our face smashing the steering wheel) it is dismissed from our mind in an effort to keep the flow of information happening as fast as possible.

It's why, after an event, we'll have the sense that there was more time involved. We can look back and find more frames of observation that we recorded in a shorter amount of time than what we normally experience. It gives the sense that there was a longer span between start and end.

There is no time dilation. There's a perception of time moving slower as you become more aware of your brain's desperate struggle to find a solution, but the "extra time" presents you with neither more information nor more room to think. The few times I've experienced this phenomenon, the bulk of the time "time dilation" was spent simply trying to process what the hell is going on.

People often describe a state of hyper-awareness, but that's only internal awareness. Your ability to process outside information during those times experiences no improvements. The result is a state where decisions are made based on very little external information besides whatever you caught of the inciting incident.

As to baseball players seeing the ball "slow down" - that's an optical illusion. Human eyes are pretty good at not just tracking but predicting movement. When tasked to press a button to stop a moving ball between two lines on-screen, people will generally press early because they intuitively "see" the ball slightly ahead of where it actually is.

A trained athlete is going to predict where the ball will go a fair bit into the future with significant precision. When recalled as a memory, that's going to come back as visual information which wasn't actually seen. In fact, human reaction time makes a decent pitcher's pitch functionally invisible in the last few meters before reaching the batter, meaning the batter's swinging at where he believes the ball will be, not literally where he sees it at the moment of impact.

Long story short, time dilation is an illusion caused by heightened awareness of one's own thought process, rather than a sudden influx of super powers.

Actually, I think that your brain does slow down time in real-time as it processes more info, but that doesn’t mean u see more things, like the last experiment tried to detect. You can’t see things that are faster than normal. Taking that eyes sees a certain frame rate, let’s say 50fps. You can’t see beyond 50 fps, but your brain processes all 50fps, so it feels slower. Your senses don’t perceive more than they usually would, but your brain processes them all, or at least most of them, making time seem slower even during real-time (even more after the fact when recalling). This is why they don’t see the time flashes in the experiment, but they do notice the frames in which they fall.

Take our brain as a computer. Let’s just randomly plug in some numbers. Imagine our brains processes external info (disregard internal feelings, thoughts etc) at a rate of 40Hz, but our eyes see things at 50fps. So our brain is usually slower than our eyes. But at times of danger, our brain ‘overclocks’ itself to 60hz, processing all 50fps and getting more post-processing of what we see. And because our internal clock is so used to 40Hz processing, when we suddenly have 60hz, our internal clock is not 1.5x faster than the actual time, making our internal clock stretch the actual time out and we feels things slower.

There is no slowing of Time, or Time dilation. You primitive fukpotatos. Animals of many species have been tested and shown to experience Time at different scales than we do because they process visual information at a much higher rates than we can. However, your brain is "ALWAYS" processing information at a much higher rate than you can visually perceive. That means that what changes is your perspective.

Your eyes however, are bound by physical limitations and can only provide information at the exact same rate as they always do, and there is always about a 2ms delay between input and perception. What happens is, your sub conscious is constantly filling in your perception (that 2ms) with filler information. This part of your brain works much faster than your conscious perception of events can register, so in times of great focus, or dire necessity, your perspective shifts slightly toward the waterfall of data pouring out of your sub conscious.

This creates the illusion of Time slowing down because the different regions of your brain work at different clock rates. What your brain is really doing, in the case of the baseball player, is simulating the path of the ball, and correcting itself millions of times per second. You cannot register that much data in conscious mind, it would take too long. So instead that 2ms of time between when you see a photon and it registers in the back of your brain is filled with a stream of simulation data directly pouring from your sub conscious.

This is ALWAYS happening in your brain. So attempting to observe it with an optical Que and a chronometer was a waste of time and money. An idiots task to say the least. There is no change in brain function. Just a change in perspective.

ok, let me explain to you guys, since you look like awesome people.

What happens is the thought flux on our head is always at full speed, like a really busy highway. You are distracted most of the time and any thought have freedom to come and go, so times seems to be really fast. BUT in life or death situations what really happens is that your brain excludes all the other non essential thoughts and that makes you feel like time is slowing down, but its not the case.

The case is, you are experiencing the real passage of time without tons of thoughts in your head. When you are at school in a boring lecture about history, you feel like time is reaaaaly slow, because you are tottaly aware of time and keeps looking to the clock. When you are enjoying a really good movie or good company, time seems to pass really fast because you are distracted by all awesome things that are happening and you are not" aware" of time itself

So, to conclude, if you are aware of time, looks like its slower than normal, when you are not aware of time, looks like is really fast.

On life death situations your brain stop all non essencial thoughts so you are really aware of the present moment because you NEED to focus on the present. The dangerous situation demands your full attention, it demmands your presence on the present time as focused as possible and because of that you become aware of time, because any decision you have to make you only have seconds to think, so time is the most important thing. Time and clarity to think , so your brain wipes out all other thoughts and really focus on time and the present momment. And THAT´S why you feel as time had slowed down.

The truth is, people more and more are experiencing time as going way too fast. The more information, the more anxiety, the more you feel you are not living your life , your dreams are not becoming true... and that´s why people suffer so much. But that is a topic for another day.
